text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- According to an immigration officials' estimation, 20,000 illegal immigrants in Estonia have received pensions and subsidies regularly while the former red passport was accepted for identification; the passport is invalid from May 15.

- President Lennart Meri was given the Hungarian Cross of Merit by the President of Hungary as an acknowledgement for developing relations between the countries; Meri will leave Budapest today and begin a visit to Slovenia.
- Representatives of the Estonian and Russian foreign ministries will meet in Helsinki at the beginning of June, Finnish prime minister Paavo Lipponen said.
- The visa-free regime between Estonia and Finland that came into force on May 1 has not caused a travel rush between Tallinn and Helsinki, shipping companies say.
- Police have arrested a man suspected of killing several older women in south Estonia last year.
- The Russian Foreign Ministry criticized the recent remarks of President Lennart Meri in Hungary who said that the signing of the Estonian-Russian border agreement was delayed because of Russia.
- Municipal Water and Sewage Department in Tallinn sold shares in the Bank of Tallinn that belonged to the city without the council's permission, the fiscal commission of the city reported.
- Tallinn city council opposition will today express no- confidence in the Centre Party deputy mayor Kalev Kallo; the motion is not expected tp pass.
- The government plans to set up a coordination commission for increasing the spread of information on Euro-integration to the public, the prime minister said.
